contentrichtext.text: {{more footnotes|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox book | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = Anna of the Five Towns | title_orig = | translator = | image = <!-- First edition cover preferred --> | caption = | author = [[Arnold Bennett]] | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = | genre = [[Novel]] | publisher = [[Chatto & Windus]] | release_date = [[1902 in literature|1902]] | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]]) | pages = <!-- ? pp --> | isbn = NA | oclc = 7016739 | preceded_by = <!-- Preceding novel in series --> | followed_by = <!-- Following novel in series --> }} '''''Anna of the Five Towns''''' is a [[novel]] by [[Arnold Bennett]], first published in 1902 and one of his best-known works.<ref>{{cite web|title=Arnold Bennett Biography|url=http://biography.yourdictionary.com/arnold-bennett|work=http://biography.yourdictionary.com/|accessdate=16 March 2013}}</ref> ==Plot summary== The plot centres on Anna Tellwright, daughter of a wealthy but miserly and dictatorial father, living in the [[Stoke-on-Trent|Potteries]] area of [[Staffordshire]], England. Her activities are strictly controlled by the [[Methodism|Methodist]] church. The novel tells of Anna's struggle for freedom and independence against her father's restraints, and her inward battle between wanting to please her father and wanting to help Willie Price whose father, Titus Price, commits suicide after falling into bankruptcy and debt. During the novel, Anna is courted by the town's most eligible bachelor Henry Mynors, and agrees to be his wife, much to her young sister Agnes' pleasure. She discovers in the end, however, that she loves Willie Price, but does not follow her heart, as he is leaving for Australia, and she is already promised to Mynors. Willie then also commits suicide. ==Bibliography== * Title: Anna of the five towns: a novel * Author: [[Arnold Bennett]] * Editor: [[Chatto & Windus]], 1902 * 360 pages * Country: England * Language: English ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:1902 novels]] [[Category:Novels by Arnold Bennett]] [[Category:Novels set in Staffordshire]] [[Category:Chatto & Windus books]] {{1900s-novel-stub}}
